dialogues.text: (suddenly stern) How did you tamper with Dr. Shrink-ROM? Bob grins, still typing.  53.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She's a tool. All you gotta do is push the right buttons. Hey, order me a pizza, huh? I missed breakfast, and this is gonna take awhile.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We have oatmeal, if you'd care to --

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: -- vomit? Order the pie. Double cheese.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Intercom BUZZES. Bob opens the door. An athletic, curvaceous PIZZA GIRL, 17, enters wearing a backwards baseball cap on her blonde, pony-tailed head.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GIRL
dialogues.text: (handing Bob the pizza) Cash or charge? Bob stares at her, dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey? He continues to stare. Qohen appears, pays the girl. She turns to go, glances back at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you staring at?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Uh... nothing. She flips her cap brim forward, adjusts her mussed pony t with both hands, perky breasts rising. She winks at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA GIRL
dialogues.text: (coyly) Wrong answer. She leaves. Qohen closes the door and turns to Bob, who stares at the door.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (snapping out of it) Whoa! I got this hormonal paradigm shift going on, 'case you didn't notice. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Puberty's hell... Was she looking at me funny?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We've grown accustomed to people looking at us funny.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you're funny looking. Bob opens the pizza box, grabs a slice, takes a huge bite sauce dribbling down his chin. He carries the box to the computer, drops it carelessly on the desk, takes another wolfish bite while typing one-handed.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mouth full) How long till Geek and Geekier come for me?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Not long.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Damn. He tosses the crust over his shoulder. Instantly, a scruf rodent bags it, drags it through a crack in the floor. Bob nods toward the pizza box.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help yourself to the rest.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We're afraid our diet precludes pizza.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Put it in the fridge, then. Bob attacks the keyboard with both hands. Qohen retrieves the pizza box, carries it toward the kitc He absently licks a bit of sauce from his finger and halt eyes closed. A look of fleeting pleasure crosses his face He opens his eyes, frowns, making sure Bob hasn't noticed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen lies in bed, tossing and turning, unable to sleep. He As It at goes to the shrine, lights a candle, stares at its flame. if against his will, he turns a picture face forward. is a close-up profile of his wife's face. She's looking something off camera, LAUGHING.  55. The picture comes to life, and she turns to face Qohen, h LAUGHTER DYING. She looks at him with pity. Qohen replaces the picture, face to the wall. He trudges to his work station, sits at the computer. Qohen touches the mouse: the menu appears. He sees Bainsley's icon, hesitates, then clicks. A live video of Bainsley fills the screen. Barely dressed white lingerie, she stretches seductively on a bed with r satin sheets, eyes closed. She MOANS passionately into a headset microphone, her hands caressing her corseted brea Raunchy CHATROOM MESSAGES scroll below her image. Qohen's head spins. Bainsley smiles wickedly, her eyes slowly opening. She li her lips with a sultry smile, then sits up, smile freezin

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (softly, into microphone) Qohen? Shocked, Qohen exits the site. He stares at his screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen lies on his bed, looking at his signature on the receipt from the Clones. Bob sits at the computer, typing furiously and softly WHEEZING. His eyes are baggy with fatigue.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We never thought of Management as a family man.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I'm it. Heir to his dark throne. Like I want it. He gave me this rap about my mom dying in childbirth, but I know she just ran off. I'm out of here too, soon as I finish my Ph.D.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Aren't you rather young for a doctorate?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It's just Quantum Systems Analysis. Old man says I shoulda finished last year. Typical control freak. Bob hits a key, and signs and symbols swiftly scroll.  56.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK, Q. You're ready to go. He stands, loses his balance, steadies himself against th desk, breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Fucking allergies. Bob takes a hit from his inhaler, sucks it in deep.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: What exactly are you allergic to? Bob pockets the inhaler, speaks through clenched teeth.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Bald old farts laying in bed instead of getting to work. Up and fucking at ‘em. Heaving a great SIGH, Qohen moves to the work station, ta his seat. He tentatively touches a key: symbols scroll. B peers over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These babies are shivering for your special touch, Q. Just like that yummy bikini babe you been playing Tarzan with. Qohen stops, mortified.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: How do you know about her?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (gesturing at computer) You kidding? Your life's an open beeping book, excuse my five-second delay... So what's she like in the virtual flesh?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: That's none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You're no fun. You sound like my dad. Qohen grudgingly types. The scrolling slows, stops. He hesitates. Types. The scrolling speeds up. Qohen stares at the screen, hands frozen above the keyboa

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's the prob, Bob?  57.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Our name is Qohen. Q--No U-- 0 --

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Come on, Q. You're looking for the least little en... tit... tee... The little entity that could. Start him up and he drags the rest behind. (pointing) Whoops! There's the little bugger!

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: There! Don't let him get away! Bob pushes Qohen out of his chair and takes his place, on hand controlling the mouse, the other swiftly typing.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gotcha, you little bastard. Bob scrolls and types at lightning speed as Qohen stands in awe. The symbols re-configure in tidy rows.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. See? Easy. Now you do it. Bob stands, and Qohen hesitantly takes his place. He star helplessly at the screen, fingers poised above the keyboa Qohen's shoulders slump in despair. Bob leans over him, coaxing. He touches Qohen's shoulder. Qohen stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We prefer not to be touched. Bob draws his hand away, his eyes going hard.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How'm I supposed to work with this? You got your head stuck so far up your ass you can't see shit. Do you even know what Zip-T's all about?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: No. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The old man says it's none of my biz. But if I was working on it long as you, you can bet your ass I'd have some clue.  58.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We only care about our call.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Don't even get me started on that. The deadlock CLICKS and the door opens. The Clones flank the doorway, arms folded.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBS
dialogues.text: Time to go, Bob. Bob ignores Chubs, still staring at Qohen.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You really are a burnout, ain't you... Get a clue, Q.

dialogues.speaker: SLIM
dialogues.text: Time to go, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Time to kiss my ass, Chubs.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBS
dialogues.text: I'm Chubs. Bob turns and heads to the door. He glares at the Clones.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: If I ever take over, you guys are fired. Slim and Chubs shoot each other worried glances.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like I'll remember who the fuck you are. They all leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen sits at his computer, scrolling through page after of neat and orderly signs and symbols, his lips unconscio forming soundless words as he strives to comprehend. The Intercom BUZZES. Qohen raises his eyes to the crucifi

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Qohen opens the door, and Bainsley is in his arms. Her trench coat flashes open, revealing she's naked underneat Qohen pulls it closed. She GIGGLES.  59.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: You're drunk. Bainsley rubs up against him.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: Mostly.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: You clicked on me.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We -- we visited your web site in error.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: Sure you did... You want me. She wraps her arms around his neck, kisses him. Qohen resists at first but then closes his eyes and, desp himself, begins to kiss her back. And now Bainsley breaks away, hot and flustered.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Easy, killer. Let a girl catch her breath! Qohen turns away, struggling to contain himself. Bainsley pulls a VR suit from her coat pocket, shakes it

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go put yours on. I'1l hook us both up to your computer. Oh! I can hardly wait! Qohen stares at the suit, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We will never wear that suit again. We... We can't ever go back there.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: Bad trip last time. I know. This time will be different. Trust me. Bainsley wraps the VR suit around Qohen's neck, pulls him close for a kiss...  60. But Qohen resists. He takes the suit from his neck, stuff it in her coat pocket, then firmly pulls her to the door.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're playing hard to get... You think that turns me on... And it does... a little... But enough's enough, Qohen. They stand in the doorway. She touches his chest, face raised to his...

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on... Let's have some fun... Qohen holds her by the shoulders at arm's length.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We don't have fun. We aren't any fun. We have work to do. And we can't imagine why you'd ever be interested in us. Bainsley's eyes blaze.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: I'm starting to wonder myself. I just didn't want to be alone tonight. She turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe you really don't have a soul... But I'm ready to find out when you are... She leaves, closing the door behind her. Qohen stares at the closed door... then, shoulders slumpi he slowly returns to his computer. He stares at the screen, rubs bleary eyes, tilts his head if listening. His eyes light on the crucifix and slowly widen as a thought occurs to him.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Impossible. He sits up straight, scrolls through the columns of signs symbols faster and faster, eyes sharp and swiftly moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen stands by the door, signing a receipt. He gives it the Clones, and they leave. Bob plops a laptop computer on Qohen's bed, inserts a wireless network card into its slot, then sits at Qohen's work station. He pulls up the Networking screen.  61.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm tapping into your network. Figure I can always play "Go Fish" with ManCom... Qohen goes to the work station, stands behind Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what's the agenda today, Q? Sit around staring at the phone? Order another pizza? I'm for pizza, myself.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We -- we think we may have discovered the purpose of the Zero Theorem. Bob pauses.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You're shitting me.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Language...

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (smiling, pleased) Give it up, Q-dog. Qohen rubs his forehead, stares up at the crucifix.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: As far as we've been able to ascertain, the Zero Theorem employs a densely compacted language that seeks to codify all known phenomena in the universe.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Try it in English, Q.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: The Zero Theorem seeks to explain the purpose of existence. Bob's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You are fuh-reaking shitting me. Holy crap. Holy crap! That is just too cool! Bob turns back to the computer, types frantically.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We nail this bad boy, we're talking groupie chicks from arts and sciences! I'm laid for life! Qohen remains silent, glumly staring. Bob looks at him.  62.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Let's roll, Q!

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: The project is impossible.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No way to know without trying.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: But if we try and fail, then you and your father won't help us to receive our call. Bob whirls around, suddenly impatient.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Quit leaning all over me, huh?. You smell like you died. Go for a walk or something, air yourself out. Qohen takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We prefer not to go out.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Then take a shower. Give your dome a turtle wax. Do anything besides stand around giving me the eye. You're creeping me out. Let me finish up here. Bob reaches for his inhaler. Hurt, Qohen backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen scrubs himself viciously with a washcloth. He stops leans against the tile, closes his eyes. The spray hits h in the face, water trickling down his cheeks like tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen quietly exits the bathroom and stops. Bob stands in front of the shrine, looking at the photos, of which are facing forward. Qohen's breath catches. His eyes burn. But then he breath deeply. He goes to the shrine, stands quietly next to Bob Bob looks at Qohen. Their eyes lock.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What happened to them?  63. Qohen stares at the photos: his Wife, his Son, his former self in various family poses, various degrees of happines

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: There was a fire. He gazes up to the chapel's charred beams, jaw set stoica

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we can never understand the reason... until we receive our call. Bob tears up. He touches Qohen's arm, drops his hand. Qohen turns a picture's face to the wall again, then anot

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We prefer that these not be touched. The memories are... painful. Bob turns away from Qohen, overwhelmed with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, Q. I feel so bad.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: It's all right. You didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No. I feel bad for lying to you. Qohen stops what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Bob walks back toward the work station, Qohen following.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Your call. Nobody can get it for you. Not my dad. Not me. Not anybody.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: But you said... Mr. Joby told us... Qohen is unable to finish. Bob raps his knuckles on the monitor, fighting tears.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (roughly) Yo, Doc, off your ass and on the clock. Doctor Shrink-ROM appears on the screen, rolling her note into a tube and twisting it nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth. Come on, I'm authorizing you.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SHRINK-ROM
dialogues.text: It's true, Qohen. Your phone call is a delusion. I've wanted to tell you... I've wanted to help you... but I was programmed to leave your peculiar pathology untreated... I'm sor -- Bob clicks her off.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: But... But why?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The old man uses everybody Q. You're a tool. We're all tools. Joby, me, that hot bikini babe...

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Bainsley?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Your call girl was paid by the hour. Qohen looks dizzy. He covers his face with both hands. Bob eases him into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll never ever lie to you ever again. That's a promise, Q. Qohen slowly lowers his hands from his face.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Our call is real. We've been waiting. It will provide our lives with purpose and meaning... a reason to go on...

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (gently) Wake up, Q.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: (desperately) Perhaps not by phone... Perhaps that was our delusion... But somehow, some way...

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: There is no call, Q. There's only Zip-T. And you and me have less than three weeks to solve it now. Qohen's eyes harden. 64.  65.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Why in the world should we bother?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Because it's your job... Qohen stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For the advancement of science... Qohen slowly shakes his head. Bob ducks his head, peeks up with pleading eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do it for me, Q...? Please...? Qohen is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Why do you care so much about the Zero Theorem?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The truth?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: That's what you promised us.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The old man told me if I helped you prove Zip-T, he'd buy me a car.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: That's it? That's your reason?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, duh... Chicks dig the wheels, Q... And soon as I get me some, I'm burning road. I'ma million light years from that bossy bastard... Come on, Q. Help a kid out. Pretty fucking please? Qohen looks into Bob's pleading eyes, softening.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Unseemly... Excited, Bob gives Qohen's shoulders a quick squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You and me, Q. Your big ass computer and my speedy little laptop. Qohen frowns.  66.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: On one condition.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Our call is real. Bob studies Qohen, then grins.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I believe you, partner. Let's go to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1. Qohen working desperately at his computer while Bob li on the bed working just as feverishly on his laptop. 2. The Clones appearing in the doorway to pick up Bob. 3. Qohen signing a receipt for delivery. 4. Qohen signing another receipt. 5. Bob taking a hit from his asthma inhaler, Qohen pausin from his work, looking at him with concern. 6. Qohen working alone on his computer late into the nigh haggard but determined. 7. Qohen kneeling at the shrine, lighting a candle. 8. Bob grabs the last slice of pizza. He takes a huge bit sees Qohen staring at him. He holds out the slice. Qohen hesitates, then takes it. He bites, swallows, smiles a sm smile, hands it back. Bob devours the rest. 9. Qohen signing yet another receipt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen sits at the computer, manipulating entities. Bob lies on Qohen's bed, headphones on, listening to musi while he works. He plays air drums while SINGING off-key. Qohen shoots him a glance, irritated. Bob hits an air cymbal.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Any progress?  67.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Impossible to tell. And you? Bob slaps his laptop closed, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm crunching in circles. He gets off the bed, stands behind Qohen at the work stat

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The old man pulls me off the job in two days. We gotta speed up the process.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps he'll give us an extension.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Not my old man. Push, push, push. I'm three years old, watching cartoons after a hard day's calculus, and he's like: (lowering voice) "Son, you'll never fulfill your destiny that way." I'm like, "Jeez, Pop, how about next commercial?" He gave up on me before I even learned to ride a bike. Qohen nods, hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Our problem is... it's pointless.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: The Zero Theorem. Follow the math. Don't you see? The point is to prove that there is no point. All of existence is a cosmic accident. It started from nothing and will end in nothing. Bob moves about the work station, idly picking up objects

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I guess that's not good.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: It would make our lives meaningless. Bob nods, distracted. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So let's prove Zip-T's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Then your father won't give you a car.  68.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Fuck him. I gotta prove something, Q. Let's do it.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don't know. Use your imagination. Qohen stares at the monitor, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Energy begets matter... Matter begets energy... According to the theorem, everything must be accounted for... In order to disprove it, we must find something that can't be counted, something outside the equation.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Such as...? Qohen closes his eyes, then suddenly opens them, realizin

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Our soul.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: It may be all we've been waiting for... but we can't imagine how to prove its existence...

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Whoa. Talk about a gnarly existential brain-burner... Bob idly opens the box that holds the VR suit, pulls it o

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +. and my brain's half-toasted as is. Bob holds the VR suit up to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some fun in the sun could help. Think that Bainsley chick would give me a freebie?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Unseemly.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'd sure like to get inside her program.  69.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We're afraid you'd find it empty. Bob stops, lost in thought. Suddenly he stuffs the suit i his pocket, grabs his laptop, and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Major breakthrough! I gotta get with ManCom and figure out the details.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: What about the Clones?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: They can fuck each other up their asses. I ain't waiting for them. I ain't waiting for nothing. I'm grabbing a cab. Bob slams the door behind him, leaving Qohen bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Language...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The Clones flank the doorway, Qohen standing before them.

dialogues.speaker: SLIM
dialogues.text: You let him go?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: How were we to stop him?

dialogues.speaker: CHUBS
dialogues.text: Duct tape works.

dialogues.speaker: SLIM
dialogues.text: Management won't be happy about this.

dialogues.speaker: CHUBS
dialogues.text: I wouldn't want to be in your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: SLIM
dialogues.text: You're in deep trouble. Qohen's jaw clenches. He smiles coldly.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Bob left a message for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen stares at the pictures, all face forward.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen sits at his computer looking longingly at Bainsley' icon. He clicks on it: "Access Denied!" Qohen slowly runs hand over his bald head. He clears the lump from his thro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Hole SCREENSAVER swirls before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A box drops in front of Qohen. He opens his eyes. Bob stands beside him, baggy-eyed, short of breath, but grinn

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Problem solved.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Lurking and working. Conferring, consorting, and hobnobbing with ManCom on the sly. Turned in my Ph.D. Dissertation while I was at it. Committee chair about had a stroke just reading the abstract. He'll flunk my ass for sure. Bob looks around the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clones were here, right? Qohen nods.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They'll be back. The old man put out an APB out on me. Every Clone in R&D's on the hunt. No time to waste, Q. Bob opens the box and pulls out the VR suit, which now sp even more wires and transistors and a crudely sewn big go "Q" on its chest. He hands it to Qohen, pushes him out of his chair, takes his place, and begins typing rapidly. Qohen eyes the suit in his hands with dismay.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: More virtual reality.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nope. I rewired it. This baby's a real live inner-space soul-search suit. All I gotta do is rig an interface with ManCom.  71.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Energy, Q-dude! Everything inside you releases energy -- from cell division to a synapse firing. This suit'll pick up the data and relay it to ManCom. If you have a soul, this'll find it... And ManCom'11l connect you to it. Bob SNEEZES, wipes his nose on his sleeve. Qohen stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't look at me like that, Q. It sounds crazy, but I got it all figured out.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We're afraid you've been studying too much philosophy and not enough physics.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You sound like my dissertation director. There's plenty of room for philosophy between subatomic particles. Bob hits a few more keys. A DIALOGUE BOX pops up: "MANCOM READY FOR INPUT".

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No time to waste. Suit up, Super-Q. Qohen picks up the suit.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We're afraid we can't wear this.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Sure you can. I even had it dry-cleaned. Qohen shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gotta. When you're connected, you'll know everything ManCom knows. Qohen delicately traces the "Q" on the suit with a finger

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Is it dangerous? Bob meets his gaze.  72.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Jesus, Q.... ManCom's the biggest, baddest neural net computer ever made... Your brain could come out like a carrot in a blender for all I know... He looks away helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Truth is, it scares the fuck out of me.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Unseemly... The Intercom BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you order a pizza?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Fucking Clones. Bob drags a pew down the aisle to block the door, WHEEZIN Qohen catches up, stops him.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: No. They have a key. Qohen touches the intercom button.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Qohen opens the door to reveal BAINSLEY. Wearing jeans an T-shirt, hair in a pony tail, she looks young and vulnera

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: Can I... come in? Qohen steps back. Bainsley enters. Spotting Bob, she raises puzzled eyes.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Bainsley -- Bob. Bob -- Bainsley. Bob is Management's son... (to Bainsley, darkly) You know Management... don't you? Bob stares at Bainsley. He takes a blast from his inhaler  73.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Qohen... Joby told me I could have the VR suit if I played along.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Then we suppose you have what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: It's not like that... Not anymore... Now I just want... you. Bob makes a GAGGING sound, then SNEEZES. He recovers.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No way, babe. You're like major league, and he's like, I mean... look at him. Bainsley steps to Bob, touches his cheek, smiling sadly.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: Please don't laugh at me. Smitten by her touch, Bob stares at her in wonder... .«.-. and Qohen stares at her in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going away, Qohen. Come with me... to a special place... an island... a real one... just for you and me. Qohen raises his eyes to the chapel's charred rafters. A pair of pigeons nest atop a crossbeam, softly COOING.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You and me -- we connected... Qohen looks deep into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can be together for real... Qohen breaks away, looks at Bob as if for an answer. Bob' face is a study in torn emotions.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Qohen...? Qohen gazes toward the shrine, all the pictures there. He hesitates, then hugs Bainsley close, whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We're afraid... we can't... Bainsley's eyes brim with tears. She kisses him softly.  74.

dialogues.speaker: BAINSLEY
dialogues.text: (desperately) Oh, run away with me, Qohen. Please? Qohen kisses her, eyes shut tight... .+. Then his eyes snap open... ++. and he backs away from her, mastering his emotions. Bainsley searches his stoic face. A SOB escapes her. She turns away and walks out. Qohen closes the door. Emotionless, he turns to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Damn, Q... You got any heart at all? Qohen doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um... Want to suit up? Qohen closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Need a break? Qohen opens his eyes, looks around the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We feel like a rat in a rat trap. Bob follows Qohen's gaze. He SNEEZES.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I been ready to gnaw my foot off since I got here. Let's get out of this tomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen stares uncertainly at the great oak door to the str

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We haven't gone out in a long time... Bob takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is bright. Qohen squints, takes a misstep, stagge  75. Bob supports him. He pulls surfer sunglasses and baseball cap from his pocket, puts them on Qohen, the cap backward

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You don't need skin cancer. They head down the street.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Can we go back now?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: There's a park just up the street. Let's air you out. You're way overdue. Qohen hugs himself, looking frail, feeble.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Should we have gone with her? Bob gives him a pitying look.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What do I know? I'm just a kid. Bob hooks his CD player on Qohen's belt, puts the headpho on Qohen's ears. He pushes "play". Qohen's eyes widen. They continue walking. A trio of OLD LADIES pushing shopp carts veers around them as they pass in the other directi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEOPLE jogging, rollerblading, picnicking, feeding pigeon A pair of sisters -- LACY, 18, and BONNIE, 15 -- try to launch a kite. It lifts, spins, nosedives. They LAUGH. Qohen and Bob sit under a big oak tree, backs against its trunk. Bob looks at Qohen, looks away, hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What's it like getting old, Q? Qohen gazes into the branches, eyes clouding, voice robot

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: You will question the worth of your life. Nothing will satisfy you. You will be alone. You will feel empty as a gourd... Qohen snaps out of it, sees Bob's consternation.  76.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse our nihilism. Bob shrugs, watches Lacy and Bonnie. The kite crashes to ground again. Lacy and Bonnie MOAN at the failure, GIGGLI

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: A little tail would make that thing more aerodynamically active. And speaking of a little tail, that girl is hot! Bonnie tries again to get the kite airborne. She shoots B a fleeting look, smiling shyly.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (wistfully) I don't know any girls my age... (snapping out of it) Think I should get a tongue stud? The question draws Qohen out of his despair.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: For what purpose?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Chicks, dude. Chicks dig the metal. Qohen stares into the distance, trying to take the questi seriously, searching for the proper response.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: In our experience, the female is attracted to the male in direct inverse proportion to the male's misguided efforts to attract her attention.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Fuckin' huh? Qohen smiles.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Chicks dig the real you. Bob reaches over, squeezes Qohen's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I bet you were a good dad, Q. Qohen attempts to speak, but his emotion overcomes him. Bob pats his arm and looks away, embarrassed. He spies a DOG VENDOR and jumps to his feet, losing his balance.  77.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa. I need food. Do us a coupla dogs, Q? Coupla wieners for a coupla weenies? Eyes misting, Qohen watches Lacy and Bonnie playing.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: May we have relish on ours? Bob grins, trots off towards the hot dog vendor.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Qohen sits deep in thought, gazing into the oak's branche The LAUGHTER of Lacy and Bonnie echoes. He looks at them. They can't get the kite airborne, but they're having fun. Qohen wrestles with a sudden impulse. Bonnie holds the kite while Lacy, at the other end of 50 of string, prepares to run with it. Qohen stands, takes off his sunglasses, takes a deep brea and tries on a smile. It fits nicely. He approaches Bonni

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Beautiful day for kite flying, isn't it? Bonnie looks at him the way one might look at a quadriple in a wheelchair. She smiles uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: BONNIE
dialogues.text: Except there's not enough wind. Lacy eyes Qohen suspiciously, drops the string and moves toward them.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We'll fix that. Qohen produces a clean handkerchief from his pocket, shak it out with a flourish, then bends down and ties it to th tail of the kite. Bob returns with one-and-a-half hotdogs, the missing half his mouth. He stops and stares at Qohen fixing the kite f the grateful girls, then quickly swallows, shoves the oth half of his hotdog in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Qohen sits beneath the oak tree, eyes closed, savoring th final bite of his hotdog. He opens his eyes with satisfaction, watches Bob and Bonn holding onto the string of the airborne kite.  78. Lacy strolls down by the pond, leaving them alone. She lo up, waves to Qohen, smiling. He waves back. Bob pulls the string: the kite dips, barely missing the ground, soars skyward. He and Bonnie LAUGH with delight. Qohen's eyes brim with joy, then slowly darken. Bob spots Qohen looking at him. He hands Bonnie the strin whispers in her ear. She smiles and squeezes his hand. Bob ambles to Qohen, plops down next to him, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Q-dog. How you doing, bud?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Well. You?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Whoa... You know? Qohen smiles, puts a hand softly on Bob's arm.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: We know.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Look... About that soul-search thing... Bob looks off at Bonnie. The kite is losing altitude. She scrambles backwards to keep it in the air.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't have to do it. I will.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: But... Why?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just to show the bastard.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: No. You're much too young. We're not at all certain -- Suddenly, Bob pokes his finger sharply into Qohen's foreh Qohen winces.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Wake the fuck up, Q! You think you're the only one who wants a call? Qohen sits dazed.  79.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Sorry. I never thought... Bob stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: I said I'm sorry. I --

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Q... Dude... You just turned singular.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: (confused) I did? (hearing himself, smiling) I suppose I did.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Jeez. I shoulda slapped you upside the head the day we met. Bob looks at Bonnie again. The kite has crashed, and she' untangling herself from a swirl of string. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess we better get back to work... Bob stands. Qohen rises too, puts a hand on his arm, stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. There's... there's someone I have to see first. Bob stares at him, uncomprehending, then breaks into a gr

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You're going after Bainsley.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: If you don't mind me leaving you here. Bob looks over at Bonnie, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Meet you back at the tomb later. Qohen hesitates. Bob playfully rubs Qohen's bald head.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go get her, Q. I can wait.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen gets into a cab, slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Where to? Qohen views him from behind: short-sleeved white shirt, t sticking out of collar, unruly hair slicked to the side. the rearview mirror: a flash of thick glasses. Qohen catches his breath. The driver looks like a Clone.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nowhere to go...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen runs from the cab, dodging traffic to the other sid the street. He races down the sidewalk, heart pounding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen sits in the rear of a nearly-empty bus, gazing out window as they travel through an upscale suburb. He closes his eyes and rests his head against the glass. When he opens his eyes, he spots a rider up front: short- sleeved shirt and tie, thick glasses. He looks around: acne-scarred faces, slicked hair, too-sh trousers, white socks in scuffed wingtips. He ducks down: this can't be real. The bus WHEEZES to a stop. A line of Clone-like men board through the front door. Panicking, Qohen jumps up and pushes through the rear doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen runs, lungs aching, GASPING. Everywhere he looks... .+. Clones: driving their cars, walking their dogs, water their begonias. Clones and more Clones, fat, skinny, shor tall, but all strangely identical in demeanor and dress.. all stopping what they're doing to stare at Qohen. He veers off the street, cuts through...  81.

dialogues.speaker: BACKYARDS
dialogues.text: ... dodging trees and flower beds, koi ponds and patio furniture... running, running, running in desperation. He vaults a fence, catches his foot, sprawls on the groun He lifts his face to the sky with a strangled SOB. Then h eyes harden. He gets to his feet, sets off running again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of breath and dishevelled, Qohen pounds on the door. Joby opens it, all jovial.

dialogues.speaker: JOBY
dialogues.text: Well if it isn't my old pal Quinn! Come in! Have a beer! Have some tap water! Joby stops, deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: JOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... You're supposed to be baby-sitting your little buddy Bob. You didn't leave him all alone, did you?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Where is Bainsley?

dialogues.speaker: JOBY
dialogues.text: Management won't like that. No... It'll be a regular Clone convention around your place, poor kid... I bet your phone's ringing off the hook even as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Bainsley. Where does she live? Joby squints in thought, taps his lip.

dialogues.speaker: JOBY
dialogues.text: Bainsley... Nope, ain't ringing a bell. Qohen grabs Joby by the shirt-front. Joby snaps to attention, eyes narrowing.

dialogues.speaker: JOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She packed up and took off. Chasing the wind. She's the least of your worries.

dialogues.speaker: _ QOHEN
dialogues.text: You're lying. You're Management's tool.  82.

dialogues.speaker: JOBY
dialogues.text: You poor bastard. We're all tools. Get used to it, Quinn. Qohen slowly releases him.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: (helplessly, by rote) My name is Qohen... QQ... His voice dies out.

dialogues.speaker: JOBY
dialogues.text: I know. I know who you are... Do you? Joby steps back, looks at Qohen with pity, shakes his hea

dialogues.speaker: JOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go home, Q... The door closes. Qohen stares at it, wracked with indecision, then suddenly takes off running down the stre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhausted, Qohen lets himself in, looks around fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Bob...? The room is dark, gloomy, lit only by the sputtering cand at the shrine and the ghostly glow of his computer. Holding pews for support, Qohen drags himself to the shri He falls to his knees, buries his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bob! After a while, he rises, wiping his face. He staggers to bed and collapses with a GROAN, exhausted and disheartene

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Bob... A RUSTLING from under the bed. Qohen jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (voice weak, gasping) Dust bunny... biosphere... down here. Bob crawls out from under the bed, shivering and COUGHING Qohen beams with joy, wraps Bob in a bear hug.  83.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clones came by twice. They'll be back. Bob SNEEZES, WHEEZES, teeth chattering. Qohen releases hi smooths Bob's sweaty hair from his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: You're burning up. Bob pushes Qohen's hand away, pulls out his inhaler.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Just a fucking fever, Q. Don't wig out.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: You need medical attention. Suddenly dizzy, Bob sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nah... Just get me some aspirin and run me a cool bath... And bar the door... No way I wanna see another Clone...

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Bob lies in the tub in his boxers. Qohen kneels beside hi

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She gave me her number. Her name's Bonnie. She's the hottest chick ever. Her sister's name is Lacy. Too old for me... You interested, Q? Qohen soothes Bob's forehead with a washcloth, silent.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So how'd you score with Bainsley?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Wish she was here giving me a bath.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: So do I... But I seem to have lost her. Bob COUGHS at length, closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Nobody's ever really lost Q-dog... We'll find her... Soon as we nail Zip-T... get your fucking call... excuse my... Bob drifts off mid-sentence. His ragged breathing softens  84. Qohen smooths back his hair, presses a cheek to his foreh lingers there, then lifts him from the tub. He drapes a towel over him, steps back, struggling under Bob's weight Qohen slips and falls against the mirror, keeping his hol Bob. Righting himself, Qohen glances to the broken mirror Amid the shattered glass, a red light shines.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPEL
dialogues.text: Qohen tucks Bob into bed. Hand on Bob's brow, he checks h temperature. He draws back his hand, still worried. BATHROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Qohen raises the ball-peen hammer and SMASHES the ManCam. Its red light blinks out.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPEL
dialogues.text: Qohen drags a pew down the aisle, stacks it against two others blocking the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPEL
dialogues.text: The door's deadlock CLICKS open. Qohen awakens with a start, sitting in a chair next to th bed where Bob still sleeps, softly SNORING. He removes hi hand from Bob's head, listening, disoriented. The door shudders, moves. Pews GROAN as they move. Qohen springs up, Bob still sleeping, and rushes to the d A THUD from outside moves the blockade. The door opens a crack. Qohen throws himself against it with all his might The THUD and GRUNT of shoulder on door, pushing Qohen bac The door opens a foot. Qohen looks around in a panic. Bob sits up in bed, bleary-eyed with fever.

dialogues.speaker: Q...
dialogues.text: Qohen sprints to the shrine, picks up the candle stand in both hands, and runs back down the aisle. Candles fly, landing in piles of computer printouts, igniting them. With a STRANGLED SCREAM, Qohen hurls the stand at the doo Wrought iron wedges. The door THUDS and THUMPS, stuck.  85. But when Qohen turns around to check on Bob, he sees: FIRE. It's a small paper fire, but in Qohen's eyes it turns to:

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Qohen fights through smoke and flames, CRASHES through a window, rolls on the ground, smoldering, SOBBING.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Qohen throws himself on the pile of burning printouts, ey clenched tight, mouth open in a soundless scream. He roll over and over, burning himself, but putting out the fire. Bob gets out of bed, wobbling with fever. He COUGHS, WHEEZES, then collapses on the bed, unconscious. Qohen rushes to him. The door bursts open, pews and wrought iron SCREECHING against the floor. Slim and Chubs push through, breathles Qohen cradles Bob in his arms. The Clones walk up the ais

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Take him to a hospital. Chubs reaches for Bob. Qohen hugs him closer for a moment then carefully places him in Chubs' arms. Bob's breathing ragged. Qohen smooths the hair from his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please. Hurry. The Clones turn to go. Slim glances at Qohen's work stati

dialogues.speaker: SLIM
dialogues.text: Your time's up. We'll be back for the hardware tomorrow. Don't touch anything. They head out the door with Bob. Qohen stares after them.

dialogues.speaker: CHAPEL
dialogues.text: Qohen kneels before the wrecked shrine, a single burning candle in his cupped hands. He stares through the flickering flame at the photos.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Qohen sits at his computer, dressed in the soul-search su  86. MONITOR: "MANCOM READY FOR INPUT". Qohen traces the "Q" on his chest, then pulls on the hood He hits the "enter" key. A low-pitched HUM as the program powers up. Monitor fills with STATIC. White noise HISSES. Qohen sits rigid, waiting. Five long seconds pass... HISSING stops. HUM winds down. Monitor blinks. The BLACK HOLE SCREENSAVER appears. Silence. Qohen raises his face to the crucifix in despair... He touches the braid of wires at the back of his hood, adjusting them, and suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: SPACE
dialogues.text: Qohen spins weightless through labyrinthine corridors. Th is no up or down. Only a dizzying expanse of computer ban stretching as far as the eye can see. Qohen weaves his way through a BUZZ of circuitry. As he approaches a computer bank, its lights FLASH, and..

dialogues.speaker: MANCOM PORTAL
dialogues.text: .»+.- Qohen is spinning headfirst through a SPARKING rain lit tunnel of circuits. Qohen is inside ManCom. His braid of wires flies behind him, shooting FLAMES. Electrical currents arc from every passing circuit board the trailing wires, creating a comet's tail of voltage. Qohen clutches his head in pain, turning sharp angles ami explosions of color, accelerating at every turn, a bolt o SCREAMING lightning. Up ahead, spinning toward him, the end of the tunnel: Spa And spinning in the center of Space: The Black Hole. Qohen closes his eyes in terror...  87. SPACE — MANCOM CONTROL - CONTINUOUS Qohen opens his eyes to find himself motionless, standing solid flooring, ManCom's computer banks behind him, the control console in front of him opening onto starry space and beyond that... the Black Hole looms. A dark Figure hunches over the control console. Qohen removes his hood, catches his breath. He steps clos

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Bob...? The Figure swivels to face Qohen. It is Management, dress in his taupe suit, the Black Hole rotating behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you won't find my son here, Mr. Leth. He's been hospitalized.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Is he... Will he be all right? Management stands, turns to face the Black Hole, his voic low and hoarse, as if speaking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: If I believed in miracles, I'd be praying for one now. My son... is not well. He's never been well. I've tried to protect him, but he's always chafed at my touch... Eventually, a father must let go. Surely you know that, Mr. Leth. He turns to face Qohen, smiling sadly. Qohen looks around.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Where, precisely, am I?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: This is your mind, Mr. Leth. This is your mind in ManCom.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Then are you real or just in my mind?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: Is there really a difference? You're part of the Neural Net now. All of your knowledge, all of your being has been incorporated into ManCom. Qohen stares in despair.  88.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: What is the answer?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: That depends upon the question. Qohen's jaw clenches.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: What am I living for?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: (amused) Good question, Mr. Leth, but posed to the wrong person. You've apparently mistaken me for an entity of considerably higher power. I am not the source of your call. I am neither God nor Devil. I am simply a man who seeks the truth.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: And what is the truth?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: You're looking it dead in the eye. He sweeps his hand toward the Black Hole behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chaos encapsulated. This is all there is in the end, as it was in the beginning. Qohen stares at the Black hole in dismay.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Then you've proven the Zero Theorem. Management sits on the edge of the control panel, frownin

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: Not quite. ManCom is still, as you put it, "crunching" the data. But it's only a matter of time. Qohen struggles to control his anger.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Why would you ever want to prove that all is for nothing? Management adjusts his tie with finicky precision.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT
dialogues.text: The saddest aspect of mankind's belief in a purpose beyond this life is that it makes this life meaningless -- a way station on the road to eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black hole swirls behind Management, a yawning maw of emptiness framing his head like a dark halo.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've persisted in believing that a call could give your life meaning. You've waited and waited for that call to come. And as a result, you've led a meaningless life. We give our own lives meaning... even if we can't understand the reason... Every rose has its thorns, Mr. Leth. Management approaches Qohen, puts a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGEMENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sadly) I'm sorry, Mr. Leth. We're not really all that different, you and I... But ultimately you must find your own way. Qohen stares at Management's hand... «+. and suddenly Management disappears. Qohen slumps for a moment, staring at the Black Hole... Then, eyes burning, he seats himself at the control panel He locates a keyboard, begins typing desperately. Nothing. Frustrated, Qohen leaps to his feet, rips the keyboard fr the panel, and hurls it at a nearby computer bank. The keyboard shatters without doing any damage, but sudde the computer bank lights up like a flashing pinball machi Qohen stares at the light-show in wonder... Frantically, he begins demolishing the control panel, hur pieces at the computer banks... He heaves up the desk-top +. and something falls CLANGING to the floor. It is a ball-peen hammer. Qohen stoops to pick it up. He holds it in his,hand, flexing its weight, smiling cold And then he goes berserk, throwing himself against bank a bank of computers, wildly swinging, SMASHING, swinging, grinning like a demon on fire... He rampages down the corridor of computer banks, hammerin And while each machine remains undamaged, all flash wild lights after he hits them, a frenzied flashing and WHIRRI that seems to match Qohen's unbridled anger.  90. He finally falls to his knees, weary, and raises his eyes All the way down the endless corridor, ManCom's computer banks are powering up. He turns and, still on his knees, gazes at the Black Hole It seems to loom closer, larger. Qohen's eyes light up like fire as the realization hits h Qohen gets to his feet. He pulls up his hood, places a ha on the "Q" on his chest, pats it for reassurance, raises hammer high... «+. then takes off at a sprint up the corridor. Computer banks flash, spark, explode in his wake... He vaults the control panel in a single bound and is sudd soaring through...

dialogues.speaker: SPACE
dialogues.text: Arms outstretched, hammer leading the way, a comet's tail fire and light trailing him, Qohen flies straight toward.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLACK HOLE
dialogues.text: It spins closer and closer, an open mouth of darkness, as Qohen streaks toward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brilliant sun is setting, half-submerged in the ocean. Qohen stands on the beach, mesmerized by the sunset. He drops his hammer, comes back to himself, turns around. The island is just the way he and Bainsley left it so lon ago. Their footsteps dot the sand. The campfire burns low He walks to the campfire, picks up the rumpled blanket, h it to his chest, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: (softly) Bainsley... He drops the blanket, stands staring at the sunset.  91. He lowers his eyes, closes them, and when he opens them.. .»+. He sees his Wife and Son sitting nearby on the beach His wife helps his son build a sand castle. Slowly, they both turn to look at Qohen. His Son waves goodbye to him, his face joyful. His Wife raises a hand i farewell, smiling and nodding slowly, as if offering him absolution, as if releasing him to live his life. Qohen smiles back, his eyes filling with tears. He turns to face the nearly-set sun again. The horizon is riot of crimson reflecting off the sea. He raises his outstretched arms, hands seeming to cradle sun. Slowly, he lets his hands descend. The sun begins to set. Qohen lowers his hands to his side and the last of the sun dips into the ocean. Qohen turns around. Stars twinkle in the darkening sky ab the jungle. He stares up at them. FADE TO WHITE. A phone softly RINGS and RINGS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen sits at his work station, fully suited and still plugged in, though the computer is dead. The phone RINGS and RINGS. He slowly pulls down his hood, stares at the RINGING phon He reaches for it, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: (under his breath) No... No more... He rubs his eyes. His fingers trail down his cheeks. With look of surprise, he feels the top of his head. His face and head show the trace of stubble. The phone stops RINGING. Qohen unplugs his braid of wires from the computer and stands, weak and dizzy.  92. He makes his way to the Shrine, gazes at the pictures the He touches the one with the broken glass, a sad smile cur his trembling lips, then wipes the tears from his eyes. He smashes the frame, slips the photo under the torso of suit, next to his heart. He takes a candle back to his work station. He touches th flame to a pile of computer printouts, starting a small f He watches as the fire grows. The phone RINGS. Distracted, irritated, Qohen snatches it up.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'm afraid you have the wrong number.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jesus, Q! I been calling for the last hour! Where the fuck you been?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: (joyfully) Bob?! Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On the way. I just left the hospital. He watches the flames grow. He eases back from the fire, trailing the phone cord behind him.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: You're... you're all right then?

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Miraculous recovery the docs refused to believe. I had to wait till everybody took a smoke break to escape. Qohen backs further away from the fire.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Listen, Q, don't put on that VR suit!

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Um... I'm wearing it right now.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well don't plug in! I heard from one of the Clones ManCom had a meltdown last night. Fucking thing's babbling like a baby on acid. Not a safe trip at all. Qohen smiles.  93.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: I'll keep that in mind.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good. Go outside and wait for me. I'll be there in a minute. The line CLICKS dead. The fire is raging now, the computer in flames, spewing noxious smoke. Qohen backs away as far as the taut phone line will allow, then punches 9-1-1 on the handset.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, I'd like to report a fire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen stands on the sidewalk, face aimed at the sunny sky PASSERSBY stare at his costume, but Qohen doesn't notice. He turns to look at his chapel. Smoke billows out the windows. He walks to the curb... .--and suddenly spots Management, flanked by Chubs and Sl standing in a shop doorway across the street. A sports car comes screeching to a halt in front of Qohen The tinted window rolls down, and Bob pokes his head out. Get in! 1 stole this from the old man. Every Clone in town'll be after me. Qohen circles the car to the passenger side. Hand on the door, he hesitates. Across the way, the Clones move forward, eyes menacing. But Management stops them with a motion of his hand. He nods to Qohen, puts a finger to his lips, and, smiling sadly, takes one last look at Bob. Then he turns and goes into the shop, the Clones followin

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (frantic) Come on, Q! Qohen gets in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Qohen puts on his seatbelt. A fire engine's siren WAILS in the distance, getting clos

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The bastard has the heat after me. Bob hits the gas and peels out, steering wildly.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Please don't refer to your father as a bastard. It's... unseemly. (hesitantly) Are you old enough to drive?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Who cares? We're on the lam, Q! Bob comes to a jerky stop at a red light. He rests his forehead on the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, Q, I can't believe what I've gone through lately. I'm totally wiped.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps you and I should take a vacation.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: I'm picturing an exotic tropical island. Bob looks at him skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You really think we can find her? Qohen gazes out the window into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know how many tropical islands there are in the world? Qohen turns to Bob, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN
dialogues.text: As it happens, I know the exact number. You're not the only genius in this car. Bob looks at Qohen and slowly breaks into a huge grin. The light turns green.  95.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What the fuck are we waiting for? Bob floors it, the tires squeal, and Qohen's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car careens down the street, barely missing a fire en going in the other direction. Qohen's wailing voice rises above the SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: QOHEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Un-fucking-seemly. FADE OUT.
